importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Madari Space's first mission into orbit is scheduled for 2026, marking a key milestone in the development of space-based data centers.
Lonestar Data Holdings plans to launch its first moon-based data center in 2027, from the Earth-moon Lagrange point L1, signaling a major step in extraterrestrial data infrastructure.
China launched 12 satellites in May 2025 as part of a space-based computing constellation, the first step in a proposed 2,800-satellite fleet.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: By 2030, data center power demand is projected to increase by 165% according to Goldman Sachs, driving urgency for alternative solutions like space-based data centers.
The article suggests that within a decade (by 2035), nearly all new data centers could be built in space due to terrestrial constraints such as land scarcity and energy demands.

keyTakeAways: Advances in AI are increasing demand for data centers, which require large amounts of land and energy, leading to high CO2 emissions.
Space-based data centers offer access to continuous solar energy, avoiding cloud cover, night, and seasonal variation on Earth.
The ASCEND project in Europe is evaluating the feasibility of space-based data centers as a more eco-friendly and sovereign solution.
To reduce emissions, space launchers would need to emit 10 times less carbon than current ones — a technological challenge not yet met.
Madari Space is conducting technical demonstrations by launching small computing payloads into orbit, with a 2026 launch planned.
China launched 12 satellites in May 2025 as the first phase of a 2,800-satellite space computing constellation.
Lonestar Data Holdings successfully tested a small data center on the moon in 2025, though it powered down early.
Starcloud is launching a satellite with an Nvidia H100 GPU in November 2025, setting a record for in-orbit compute power.
Lonestar has a $120 million deal with Sidus to launch six data storage satellites by 2027, with each doubling in storage capacity.
Space-based data centers face major challenges including heat dissipation in a vacuum, radiation, maintenance, space debris, and solar flares.
Experts like Quentin A. Parker of HKU argue that terrestrial data centers remain cheaper and more practical, and space-based solutions face significant economic and technical drawbacks.
Proponents like Shareef Al Romaithi believe that space-based computing is essential to avoid technological stagnation due to Earth-based resource exhaustion.

namedEntities.name: ASCEND project
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A European Commission-funded initiative evaluating the feasibility of space-based data centers to reduce carbon emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ASCEND project is central to the article’s discussion on whether space-based data centers are viable and environmentally beneficial.

namedEntities.name: Thales Alenia Space
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A France-based company that led a European Commission-funded study on the feasibility of space-based data centers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Thales Alenia Space conducted a key feasibility study for the ASCEND project, concluding that space-based data centers could offer a more eco-friendly and sovereign solution with continuous solar access.

namedEntities.name: Madari Space
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Abu Dhabi-based startup collaborating with Thales Alenia Space to launch small computing components into orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Madari Space is one of the few companies actively launching technical demonstrations of space-based computing, with a 2026 mission scheduled to send a toaster-sized payload into orbit.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation that launched 12 satellites in May 2025 as the first phase of a 2,800-satellite space computing constellation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China's launch demonstrates that space-based computing is already being implemented, marking a significant real-world step in the development of orbital data centers.

namedEntities.name: Lonestar Data Holdings
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Florida-based company that successfully tested a small data center on the moon in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lonestar Data Holdings is a pioneer in moon-based computing, showing tangible progress toward extraterrestrial data center operations despite early technical setbacks.

namedEntities.name: Starcloud
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Washington state-based startup launching a satellite with an Nvidia H100 GPU in November 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Starcloud aims to set a record for in-orbit compute power, highlighting the growing interest in space-based processing with advanced AI hardware.

namedEntities.name: SpaceX
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rocket launch company that provides launch services for space-based data center missions, including rideshare for Lonestar’s satellites.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SpaceX enables cost-effective access to space through its Falcon launch vehicles, which are currently used to transport data center payloads into orbit.

namedEntities.name: Sidus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A spacecraft provider that has signed a $120 million deal with Lonestar Data Holdings to build and support on-orbit data storage satellites.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sidus is critical to the logistics and deployment of Lonestar’s moon-based data center satellites, ensuring on-orbit infrastructure support.

namedEntities.name: UNOOSA (United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international agency that supports the Access to Space for All Initiative, which includes Madari Space’s orbital mission.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: UNOOSA provides a global framework and support for inclusive space access, which is foundational to Madari Space's mission and outreach.

namedEntities.name: Goldman Sachs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A financial institution that projected a 165% increase in data center power demand by 2030.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Goldman Sachs’ projection underscores the urgency for innovative data center solutions due to rising energy and land demands on Earth.

namedEntities.name: Quentin A. Parker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Laboratory for Space Research at the University of Hong Kong, who criticizes the economic viability of space-based data centers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parker provides a skeptical, expert counterpoint to the proponents, highlighting risks like cost, radiation, debris, and maintenance issues.

namedEntities.name: Nvidia H100 GPU
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A high-performance graphics processing unit used in Starcloud’s satellite for in-orbit computing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The use of Nvidia H100 GPUs signals a move toward high-performance AI computing in space, which is essential for advanced data processing.

namedEntities.name: Earth-moon Lagrange point L1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A point 60,000 kilometers from the moon where Lonestar’s first data center will operate.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The L1 point offers a stable location for data centers with reduced Earth interference and consistent solar access, making it ideal for orbital computing.

namedEntities.name: Shareef Al Romaithi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Founder and CEO of Madari Space, who advocates for space-based data centers to reduce data lag and enable timely decisions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al Romaithi is a key proponent of space computing, promoting its benefits for Earth observation and timely decision-making.

namedEntities.name: Philip Johnston
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CEO of Starcloud, who predicts that nearly all new data centers will be in space within 10 years.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johnston’s prediction underscores the growing belief among industry leaders that space-based data centers are inevitable due to terrestrial limitations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Advances in artificial intelligence are driving a massive increase in demand for data centers, which require vast amounts of land and energy, contributing significantly to carbon emissions. To address these issues, companies and researchers are exploring space-based data centers as a solution, leveraging continuous solar energy and reduced land use. Projects like the European ASCEND initiative and startups such as Madari Space, Lonestar Data Holdings, and Starcloud are actively testing small-scale space computing systems. China has launched early satellites in a planned constellation, while Lonestar has tested a moon-based data center. However, major challenges remain, including high launch costs, radiation, heat dissipation, space debris, and the difficulty of maintenance. While experts like Quentin A. Parker question the economic and practical viability, proponents argue that space-based computing is essential to avoid technological stagnation due to Earth-based resource exhaustion. The sector is still in its infancy, with significant technological and financial hurdles to overcome before space-based data centers become a mainstream alternative.
title: Why these companies want to send data centers into space
